detailed_results.context:
A 7‑year‑old boy presented with progressive ataxia, cranial nerve VI palsy, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) consistent with a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG). Histologic confirmation via stereotactic biopsy revealed a World Health Organization grade IV diffuse midline glioma with the H3‑K27M mutation and a concurrent ACVR1 G328V mutation. Molecular profiling showed an unmethylated MGMT promoter and wild‑type TP53. The patient received standard focal radiation therapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions) followed by six cycles of temozolomide (75 mg/m²/day) as per the St. Jude protocol; treatment was discontinued after the third cycle because of grade 3 neutropenia (absolute neutrophil count <500/µL). 

Six months after radiation, the patient was enrolled in a Phase II clinical trial (NCT04567890) evaluating the combination of the dopamine receptor D2 antagonist ONC201 and the histone deacetylase inhibitor panobinostat. The protocol administered ONC201 orally at 625 mg twice weekly and panobinostat orally at 20 mg three times weekly, concurrently with a re‑irradiation boost of 30 Gy in 10 fractions. The trial’s interim analysis reported a median overall survival of 15 months and a 6‑month progression‑free survival rate of 70 %. The most common treatment‑related adverse events were grade 3 fatigue (12 % of patients) and grade 2 thrombocytopenia (8 %). No cases of grade 3 or higher neutropenia were observed in the cohort. The patient’s baseline neurocognitive function had declined modestly during the initial radiation course but remained stable during the trial. 

Given the absence of severe hematologic toxicity on the current regimen, the treating team is evaluating the underlying reasons for this favorable safety profile.

detailed_results.context:
A 7‑year‑old male presented with a 3‑month history of worsening gait instability and diplopia. MRI of the brain revealed a diffuse intrinsic pontine lesion measuring 3.2 cm in maximal diameter, consistent with diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG). A stereotactic biopsy demonstrated a WHO grade IV diffuse midline glioma with the following molecular profile: H3‑K27M mutation positive, ACVR1 G328V mutation present, and MGMT promoter unmethylated.

The patient received standard focal radiation therapy to a total dose of 54 Gy in 30 fractions over six weeks. Six weeks after completion of radiation, follow‑up imaging showed stable disease. Given the presence of the H3‑K27M mutation, he was enrolled in a Phase I dose‑escalation trial of the imipridone ONC201. He received ONC201 orally at 625 mg/m² once weekly. After two cycles, MRI demonstrated a 40 % reduction in tumor volume, meeting criteria for a partial response. He tolerated ONC201 well, with only grade 1 fatigue and transient nausea.

After six cycles of ONC201 (approximately 6 months from trial entry), surveillance MRI revealed new areas of contrast enhancement at the dorsolateral pons and a modest increase in overall tumor size (approximately 10 % growth from nadir), indicating disease progression despite ongoing therapy. Laboratory studies remained within normal limits, and there were no new neurologic deficits.

Concurrently, a separate open‑label Phase II study evaluating the histone deacetylase inhibitor panobinostat in pediatric patients with H3‑K27M‑mutant DIPG reported a median overall survival of 15 months compared with the historical control median of 11 months (p = 0.03). In that trial, panobinostat was administered at 20 mg/m² intravenously twice weekly for three weeks of a 28‑day cycle. Grade 3–4 toxicities occurred in 30 % of patients, most commonly thrombocytopenia and transaminase elevation, but were manageable with dose adjustments.

A combination regimen of ONC201 plus panobinostat has not been studied in children, and pre‑clinical data suggest potential synergistic antitumor activity but also raise concerns for additive hematologic toxicity. Re‑irradiation with stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) delivering 20 Gy in a single fraction is an option for focal progression, but cumulative radiation dose to the brainstem exceeds 70 Gy, increasing the risk of radionecrosis.

The treating multidisciplinary team must decide the next line of therapy based on the patient’s molecular profile, prior treatment response, and the safety/efficacy data presented.
